title: SB 1.17.39 | HH Stoka Krishna Swami | 20-03-2023 | Daily Evening Bhagavatam Discourse
speaker: HH Stoka Krishna Swami

segments.key_quote: In this session we are discussing from the 39th verse of the 17th chapter of the 1st canto of Shri Madbhagavatam.
segments.summary: The speaker begins with devotional chants and announces the topic of discussion: verse 39 of chapter 17, canto 1 of Srimad Bhagavatam.

segments.key_quote: Now Kali Purusha asked something more because at the time Pariksit was ruling Kali Purusha could not find in Pariksit's kingdom any place where these four activities were going on.
segments.summary: The speaker explains that Kali asked for more places to reside because King Pariksit's rule was so pure that the four sinful activities (gambling, intoxication, illicit sex, and animal slaughter) were not present.

segments.key_quote: the king gave him permission to live where there is gold where this gold means where people have accumulated gold for purposes other than devotional service other than for serving krishna other than krishna conscious purpose
segments.summary: Kali Purusha surrendered to Pariksit and begged for another place to reside, so the king gave him permission to live where there is gold accumulated for non-devotional purposes.

segments.key_quote: wherever there is gold which is not utilized for devotional service there is also falsity intoxication lust envy and enmity these five things are there wherever gold is accumulated and not utilized for uh devotional service
segments.summary: The speaker explains that gold not used for devotional service breeds falsity, intoxication, lust, envy, and enmity, and that during Pariksit's reign, such places were rare.

segments.key_quote: Maharaj Parikshit thus gave Kali permission to go. He gave Kali permission to live in a place where there is gold, because wherever there is gold, there are all the above mentioned four things and over and above them there is enmity also.
segments.summary: The speaker elaborates on Kali Purusha's nature as a friend of irreligion (Adharma) and how Parikshit Maharaj allowed him to reside where gold is accumulated, as it fosters falsity, intoxication, lust, envy, and enmity.

segments.key_quote: If somebody accumulates gold and does not use gold for devotional service, such gold encourages five things, falsity, intoxication, prostitution, envy and enmity.
segments.summary: The speaker reiterates the four defects of accumulating gold for non-devotional purposes: falsity, intoxication, lust, and envy, adding that enmity is also present.

segments.key_quote: Gold standard currency is based on falsehood because the currency is not on a par with the reserve gold.
segments.summary: The speaker transitions to a discussion of government policy, arguing that a gold standard currency is inherently based on falsity because the value of currency notes issued is not equivalent to the gold reserves held by the government.

segments.key_quote: The basic principle is falsity because currency notes are issued in value beyond that of the actual reserve gold.
segments.summary: The speaker uses the example of currency notes exceeding the value of reserve gold to illustrate how gold encourages falsity, and how this artificial inflation of currency leads to the prostitution of the state economy.

segments.key_quote: The price of commodities becomes artificially inflated because of bad money or artificial currency notes.
segments.summary: The speaker explains how the economy is ruined by artificial inflation, where the supply of currency notes exceeds the value of available goods, leading to increased prices and scarcity.

segments.key_quote: Instead of paper currency, actual gold coin should be used for exchange.
segments.summary: The speaker suggests using gold coins as currency instead of paper notes to prevent the misuse of gold and eliminate falsity in the economy, also suggesting regulation of gold ornaments for women by quantity.

segments.key_quote: Prabhupada's recommendations are very practical and that is why you find in the Vedic culture they had only gold coins.
segments.summary: The speaker concludes by emphasizing the practicality of Prabhupada's recommendations, noting that Vedic culture used gold coins, which prevented artificial inflation, a problem prevalent in countries with paper currency.
The speaker concludes the session with a thank you.
